Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2012 12:41PM - edited Jan 13, 2012 12:42PM by gardengumby I had 3 drains after DIEP stage I.  One (the breast) came out after 2 weeks.  The other two remained in for 5 weeks.  They finally took them out - even though I was still producing over 60 ml per drain as they had been in for so long.  I did get a seroma after they were pulled, but used heavy-duty compression garments for a few weeks, and that seemed to go away.  I do notice that I have slightly increased scarring in the vicinity of where the tubes were, but am hopeful they will fix that when I get around to stage II in May.
Posts.Title: still have drain 3.5 weeks after DIEP - is this normal? txstardust txstardust

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2012 10:13AM gardengumby wrote: I was at work, in a "team building" meeting when I received the call.  Since I had walked out of the meeting without anything but the phone, I had to walk back in with tears streaming down my face to get a notebook and pen so I could write down some information.  I called my husband who came to pick me up, but in the meantime told my boss.  Later I told the rest of my team, and explained that I would have a fair amount of absence for a bit.  That I knew they'd all pick up the slack and that I really appreciated all of their help and good thoughts.  We phoned our children, my husband called his family.  Emailed other relatives.  My parents were already gone. I told my husband I didn't care who he told, as I knew he would need support, too.  In many ways this whole ordeal has been more difficult for him than for me.  Having something done to you is IMO not as difficult as feeling helpless when things are being done to a loved one.

Posts.Content: May 20, 2012 08:36AM gardengumby wrote: Lymph involvement lets you know that it has started traveling, but BC can also travel via your blood - ergo no nodal involvement but still can get mets - one of the reasons IMO we need to take whatever medications are available....
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: May 24, 2012 12:40AM gardengumby wrote: Linda, I don't know your age, but tamoxifen almost killed me.  I didn't do either rads or chemo, and had positive nodes.  I'm taking letrozole (generic femara) now.  The femara has some difficulties, but I'm doing much MUCH better on it than on tamoxifen.  If you're pre-menopausal, you may want to consider an ooph to widen the range of things you can take.  If you're post-menopausal (as I am), then there are definitely other options that may be available to you.

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2011 09:22AM - edited Oct 27, 2011 09:23AM by gardengumby I was diagnosed October of 2010.  As part of the overall diagnostic procedure they did biopsies of my lymph nodes and found cancer on my left side (same side as the breast that showed cancer).  They then performed a PET/CT scan to check for mets and found none.  Final diagnosis was Stage IIa - had a mastectomy and they took the lymph as well - I tested positive in 2 of 19 nodes.  They treated me very conservatively.  No rads because only 2 nodes were affected, no chemo because testing for the oncotype put me at 14.  I was on tamoxifen for 6 months, but developed blood clots, so my oncologist wants me on an AI after the clots clear (they figure a couple more months before I'm on any meds again). I'm really nervous about recurrence, because the treatment has been ultra-conservative.  At the same time, because my body over-reacts to just about everything - I'm VERY thankful I didn't have either rads or chemo.
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 03:58PM gardengumby wrote: First, good luck.  Making the decision to do chemo or not is rough.  I was node positive, my IDC was a little over a cm (13mm for the largest), but multi-focal and grade 2.  My oncotype score was 14.  I chose not to do chemo, as I have a history of being extremely sensitive to chemicals and drugs.  When it turned out I couldn't do tamoxifen I got a little nervous, but the AI (letrozole) seems to be working for me.  So far so good....  :)
Posts.Title: Any help for us English Ladies on OncotypeDX test DizzyD DizzyD

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2012 05:18AM gardengumby wrote: Thank-you all so much.  I'm really scared right now - hopefully for no good reason.  I'll see my oncologist tomorrow.  I want her to schedule a PET scan, as that will clear things up (I is or is not stage IV).  Not crazy about all the radiation that introduces, but right now I figure the stress probably isn't doing me a whole lot of good either. If the nodules were well defined, I wouldn't be as worried, but 3 of the 5 nodules are "ill-marginated" which doesn't bode all that well, I don't think - not that I really know anything...  :(. I have a life-long history of asthma, so know that there is a possibility that these are caused by a combo of the PE's and/or asthma, but the head never takes the positive direction - it immediately aims for the worst possible outcome donchaknow...  on the plus side, if it is stage IV - definitely not good, but like I told my husband this morning, my aunt lived with stage IV for about 15 years - so he's still stuck with me for a good many years regardless.  :)
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: May 10, 2012 01:58PM gardengumby wrote: lmflynn - what medication are you on for the cancer?  Some of the AI's are wicked hard on bone and are known to increase bone pain.  Bone loss does not equal bone cancer, but bone loss/arthritis certainly can equal pain.  I get a lot of back pain and have had my fair share of freaking out that I've got mets - but haven't actually had them - just had the freak out.  :)    Try not to dwell too much on the bad "could be's".  Whatever life we all have left needs to be mostly fun - not just worry and fear.  :)
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: May 19, 2012 03:44AM - edited May 19, 2012 03:45AM by gardengumby mzmerz - don't think about different things you could have done.  I'm post-menopausal and they started me on tamoxifen.  I'd still be on it (timewise) but my body simply would NOT put up with the drug, so I was moved to an AI.  The last I read was that 2.5 years tamox and 2.5 years AI is recommended.  My mom was also post-menopausal when diagnosed (she was 20 years older than I was when I was diagnosed).  She was put on tamoxifen and had no re-currence, whereas both her sister and her mother were stage IV when diagnosed.  It's just a crap-shoot. Congratulation DJ - so glad you are alright.  Getting old does suck :)
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: May 24, 2012 12:57AM gardengumby wrote: Some things I won't remember, as it was about 9 months ago I went off it and onto letrozole, and frankly I have no memory anymore...  But, to begin with I had zero energy.  All I ever wanted to do was sleep.  I'd get home from work and go pretty much straight to bed.  Then I started having difficulty breathing, I've always had asthma, but I've controlled it by diet for a long long time, and I couldn't anymore.  Then I started getting terrible pain in my feet.  Then portions of my feet around my toes would lose sensitivity.  I could BARELY walk.  Then I got blood clots.  Had a DVT from my foot to my groin and multiple in my lungs.  Then finally the oncologist said no more tamoxifen and put me on letrozole....  well, to be honest, I said I would not take tamoxifen anymore and she'd better find something else to give me...  But my mother took it for 10 years with NO side-effects, so ya just never know....
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2012 12:43AM gardengumby wrote: MRDRN - good luck with the lesion.  If it brings you any peace, I have "something" on my liver as well (I can't remember if it was referred to as a lesion or not, anymore).  Anyway, it was present when I was first diagnosed with BC.  The PET/CT scan didn't react, so they weren't worried about it.  Of course, it showed up in my last CT scan as well, and was still unchanged.  In other words, your lesion may not be anything overly worrisome, but all the testing can be pretty scary. Good luck.

Not exactly professional, but I wasn't thinking very clearly at the time.

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2012 11:48AM - edited Jun 21, 2012 11:55AM by gardengumby My diagnosis was very close to that of YorkieMom.  I had 2 positive nodes (axillary), had an oncotypeDX score of 14.5, so no chemo.   I'm a person who has always reacted very harshly to any kind of medication/chemical, so I was really worried about chemo, and overjoyed at it not being "required" due to the result of the oncotype test.  On occasion I've been worried (of course) about recurrence but I doubt that I'd be less worried if I did chemo...  (I'm a bit of a worry wart)

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 05:27PM gardengumby wrote: Be aware of the fact that some people simply cannot take tamoxifen (I am one).  My mother tolerated it very easily, not so for me.  That said, if there was anything I could have done to not have a mastectomy, I would have - in a heartbeat.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen Vs Mastectomy winter2011 farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 06:40PM gardengumby wrote: Did you have a radical or a modified radical MX?  The difference (as I understand it) is that with a modified radical (which I had) you have 2 separate incisions, one removing the breast, a second removing the lymph.  The radical, you have only one incision, as a result much more muscle is severed as well as nerves, which would probably lead to increased numbness.. I had my MX a little over a year ago.  I have no numbness in my back, or fingers.  There is some on the underside of my arm, near my armpit.  The "pit" itself is pretty much totally numb.  On occasion I have a stabbing pain here and there, and figure that's a nerve trying to find it's way home, so I don't get too stressed over it.
Posts.Title: A year after MX still numb Braveheart curveball

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2013 01:09PM - edited Jul 24, 2013 01:09PM by gardengumby I don't see how it could be fat necrosis with no reconstruction.  Fat necrosis comes from the fat that they use to build your new breast not getting enough blood supply and hardening.  But I'm no surgeon, nor nurse, so that's just my opinion - I wouldn't take it to the bank or anything. I would assume scar tissue, but as all of us have paranoia issues at this point, I would hie thee to the dr as soon as he/she is available.
